heroDescription: The PSRπ project was the pioneering first phase of our pulsar astrometry program, operating from 2010 to 2013. This initiative targeted 60 ordinary pulsars with the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA), achieving unprecedented sub-milliarcsecond precision for parallax and proper motion measurements.
overview: The PSRπ project was the first large-scale pulsar astrometry program using the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA), focusing on measuring precise distances and velocities of radio pulsars through parallax and proper motion determinations.

From 2010 to 2013, we conducted a systematic campaign of observations targeting 60 carefully selected pulsars distributed across the Galactic plane. By implementing innovative phase-referencing techniques, we achieved unprecedented astrometric precision for these distant neutron stars.

This pioneering project resulted in 53 significant parallax measurements, which represented a dramatic increase in the number of pulsars with well-measured distances. These measurements have helped refine pulsar population models, improved our understanding of the Galactic electron density distribution, and provided valuable insights into neutron star formation mechanisms.

statistics.label: Publications
statistics.description: Scientific papers based on project data

timeline.title: Project Planning
timeline.description: Development of the PSRπ program concept and initial target selection for the first large-scale pulsar astrometry campaign.

timeline.title: First Observations
timeline.description: Commenced VLBA observations of the first set of target pulsars using traditional phase-referencing techniques.

timeline.title: Methodology Refinement
timeline.description: Developed enhanced calibration procedures to improve astrometric precision, particularly for fainter targets.

timeline.title: Preliminary Results
timeline.description: First analysis of parallax measurements for a subset of pulsars, revealing the potential for systematic improvements to the pulsar distance scale.

timeline.title: Project Completion
timeline.description: Final observations conducted, completing the baseline necessary for precise parallax measurements.

timeline.title: First Results Published
timeline.description: Publication of initial results for 19 pulsars, demonstrating the success of the measurement technique.

timeline.title: Complete Catalog Release
timeline.description: Release of the full PSRπ catalog with astrometric measurements for all 60 target pulsars.

objectives.title: Establish Distance Scale
objectives.description: Develop a reliable, model-independent cosmic distance ladder for pulsars to replace dispersion measure-based distances which can have errors of >50%.

objectives.title: Measure Galactic Distribution
objectives.description: Determine the spatial distribution of pulsars throughout the Galaxy to constrain neutron star population synthesis models.

objectives.title: Characterize Pulsar Velocities
objectives.description: Measure the distribution of pulsar transverse velocities to understand their birth kicks and subsequent Galactic dynamics.

objectives.title: Refine Electron Density Model
objectives.description: Improve models of the Galactic free electron density distribution by comparing independent distance measurements with dispersion measures.

objectives.title: Enable Future Precision Studies
objectives.description: Create a foundation for future high-precision pulsar timing studies by providing accurate astrometric parameters.

technicalApproach: The PSRπ program utilized the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) at L-band (1.4 GHz) to achieve the highest possible astrometric precision. Each target pulsar was observed at 6-8 epochs spread over approximately 2 years, with epochs strategically scheduled near the times of maximum parallactic excursion.

We implemented phase-referencing techniques to calibrate atmospheric effects, using compact extragalactic radio sources as position references. For many targets, we included observations of in-beam calibrators — background sources that appear in the same primary beam as the target pulsar — to reduce systematic errors.

To optimize sensitivity for the relatively faint pulsar signals, we implemented pulsar gating during correlation. This technique increases the signal-to-noise ratio by accumulating data only during the on-pulse portion of the pulsar's rotation, effectively reducing the noise contribution from the off-pulse intervals.

Data calibration and imaging were performed using a customized pipeline developed specifically for pulsar astrometry, addressing the unique challenges of these observations. Positional measurements and their uncertainties were determined through fitting to the interferometric images, with careful attention to systematic error analysis.

keyResults.title: Vela Pulsar Kinematics
keyResults.description: Achieved the most precise measurement of the Vela pulsar's proper motion and parallax, confirming its association with the Vela supernova remnant and refining its age estimate to 11,000 ± 500 years.

keyResults.title: Crab Pulsar Distance
keyResults.description: Resolved the long-standing discrepancy in the distance to the Crab pulsar, obtaining a parallax measurement of 0.27 ± 0.03 milliarcseconds, corresponding to a distance of 3.7 ± 0.4 kpc.

keyResults.title: Pulsar Velocity Distribution
keyResults.description: Established that the transverse velocity distribution of ordinary pulsars is bimodal, with peaks at approximately 200 km/s and 400 km/s, suggesting two distinct neutron star formation channels.

keyResults.title: Local Electron Density Anomalies
keyResults.description: Discovered significant deviations from existing Galactic electron density models, particularly in the direction of the Gum Nebula, requiring substantial revisions to these models.

scientificImpact: The PSRπ program has fundamentally transformed our understanding of the Galactic pulsar population. By providing model-independent distances to a statistically significant sample of pulsars, we have placed pulsar population studies on a firm empirical foundation for the first time.

Our measurements have revealed systematic biases in previous distance estimates based on dispersion measures, leading to significant revisions of the Galactic electron density model. These improvements benefit not only pulsar astronomy but also studies of fast radio bursts and other transient phenomena.

The precise space velocities derived from our measurements have provided crucial insights into neutron star formation, confirming that many pulsars receive substantial kicks at birth and revealing correlations between kick magnitude and other pulsar properties.

publications.citation: Deller, A. T., Boyles, J., Lorimer, D. R., et al. (2013). VLBI Astrometry of PSR J2222-0137: A Pulsar Distance Measured to 0.4% Accuracy. The Astrophysical Journal, 770(2), 145.

Chatterjee, S., Brisken, W. F., Vlemmings, W. H. T., et al. (2009). Precision Astrometry with the Very Long Baseline Array: Parallaxes and Proper Motions for 14 Pulsars. The Astrophysical Journal, 698(1), 250-265.
Brisken, W. F., Benson, J. M., Goss, W. M., & Thorsett, S. E. (2002). Very Long Baseline Array Measurement of Nine Pulsar Parallaxes. The Astrophysical Journal, 571(2), 906-917.
Deller, A. T., Vigeland, S. J., Kaplan, D. L., et al. (2016). The PSRPI catalogue: VLBA astrometry of 60 pulsars. The Astrophysical Journal, 828(1), 8.

pulsarsStudied.overview: The PSRπ program astrometrically studied 60 ordinary pulsars selected based on their signal strength and sky distribution.
pulsarsStudied.catalogueInfo: This is a general overview of the pulsars studied in the PSRπ project. For comprehensive details, measurements, and analysis, please refer to the full catalogue paper:
pulsarsStudied.catalogueTitle: The PSRPI catalogue: VLBA astrometry of 60 pulsars

dataPipeline.description: All PSRπ data was processed using a standardized pipeline developed for pulsar astrometry. This approach ensures consistent results across all sources and enables systematic error analysis.

steps.title: VLBA Observation
steps.description: Data collection using the Very Long Baseline Array with 8-hour observation sessions per target, typically across 6-8 epochs over 2 years.

steps.title: Pulsar Gated Correlation
steps.description: Raw data correlated with pulsar gating using the VLBA correlator, enhancing signal-to-noise by 40-70% by excluding off-pulse data.

steps.title: A Priori Calibration
steps.description: Initial calibration including ionospheric correction, Earth orientation parameter updates, and amplitude calibration using measured system temperatures.

steps.title: Phase Referencing
steps.description: Transfer of phase solutions from primary calibrator sources to the target pulsar to correct for atmospheric and instrumental effects.

steps.title: Pulsar Imaging
steps.description: Production of interferometric images of the target pulsar for each epoch, with careful attention to data weighting and resolution optimization.

steps.title: Position Measurement
steps.description: Determination of precise pulsar positions at each epoch through two-dimensional Gaussian fitting to the interferometric images.

steps.title: Astrometric Parameter Fitting
steps.description: Least-squares fitting of five astrometric parameters (position, proper motion, parallax) to the multi-epoch position measurements.
